name: Gabriel Deck from Berkeley
You Ain't Got Time To Bleed!
description:
NBN FA with a focus on surprise flatline. The idea is to have 2 win conditions to rely on depending on how the game is going.

Thoughts? What do you think could be done differently? I tried Snoop; it didn't work so well for me. Also tried both Punative and Edge of World, but while they worked when they worked, it was always an edge case. I used to have less ICE, but Medium/Keyhole is terrible. :P

name: Kate's ICE Key
description:
My retooled Kate ICE destruction deck, with Keyhole and Mag added in. Some thoughts:

46 cards because I want to Infiltration; if I'm going to waste Parasites to get into a remote, it better be worth it.

3 Mem Chips? Keyhole and Mag is 4 MU off the bat, and 1 Grimoire is hard to rely on.

Atman is for when it make more sense to just break something than waste a parasite on it. Almost always will come out at 0 strength if Datasucker is out.

Thoughts?

name: Noise Core Set
Andy Event Runner V2.1
description:
The inclusion of 3 Prepaid Voice Pads allows for a lot of events in the deck (note the absence of RnD Interface and the inclusion of the Maker's Eye). And with True Colours and the pads, Lawyer Up is something to behold.

Quick Masanori and 1 event almost for free each turn will soon cripple your opponent. And if it is still not over, Levy and here we go again. It is really fun to look the face of the Jinteki player when you have run out of cards and then play a Levy or a Same Old Thing for the Levy.

Been playing a lot with this deck, with very good results for the last 3-4 months.

name: Suicide Noise (wrath)
Whizzard does Oldschool v1.1
description: Money and Breakers. Pure as heaven, efficient as hell. Try to get to late game fast!

name: NBN #3 - Restructuring News
description:
1) Cheap ices early on to be able to play Restructure. If cheap/economy ices are not drawn early on, Celebrity Gift and MMC are there as second plans to reach 10 credits easily.

2) Use the credits to score agenda : - by fast advancement (big ices and SanSan) - by tags (Midseason Replacements + Psychosographics)

Jackson Howard is of great help here : - to draw the card we need to ramp up to 10 credits - to shuffle back archives to R&D (because of Celebrity Gift)

name: NBN #3 - Restructuring News v2
description:
======= changes made to v1 ========= MMC -2 Celebrity Gift -3 Sweeps Week +3

Scorched Earth +2

1) Cheap ices early on to be able to play Restructure. If cheap/economy ices are not drawn early on, Celebrity Gift and MMC are there as second plans to reach 10 credits easily.

2) Use the credits to score agenda : - by fast advancement (big ices and SanSan) - by tags (Midseason Replacements + Psychosographics)

Jackson Howard is of great help here : - to draw the card we need to ramp up to 10 credits - to shuffle back archives to R&D (because of Celebrity Gift)

name: Viewing Habits of Middle-Aged White Female Company Directors
description:
A FA deck with a few twists. The ice is a mix of early (Paper Wall, Enigma, Wall of Static), mid (RSVP, Bastion, Grim) and late (Tollbooth, Archer, Flare) game. Security Subcontract trashes your Pop-Ups and Paper Walls before the runner gets a chance to, turning them into cash to fuel either your fast advance or beefier ice on your centrals. RSVP protects SanSan and Haas - it'll cost the runner 8 credits to get through and trash either with a Gordian, or they'll have to acquire a Datasucker token in combo with Yog.

Economy is standard Operations fair, with Gila Hans and Security Subcontract for on-demand bursts if needed.

Director Haas is a weird choice - I found I had 5 influence left over and no real idea what to spend it on, so I took a chance. She works very well; behind an RSVP she can safely sit on the table for a turn and get a 3/2 agenda scored for cheaper than a SanSan or a Biotic Labor. If you score an APP with her then you can replace her with another 3/2 next turn and score it from hand, and now she's safely in archives. Alternatively, you can dare the runner into making a costly run to capture her, allowing you to set up for the rest of your game. If they don't run on her, woo, 4 clicks!

Special mention goes to Snare - once the first Sweeps Week has been played runners will often operate on low hand-size to mitigate the bonus. When you combine that with reckless runs in an attempt to stop the first APP from getting scored, runners will often flatline or end their turn with a tag. (Closed Accounts punishes this mistake further, and is also an effective response to Tag-Me Siphon.) Archer and Flare have both pulled their weight as most runners don't see either coming - Flare is especially good against an early game Desperado, and Archer creates enough of a tempo swing to let you turn that sacrificed Breaking News into a scored 3/2.

name: Untitled
description:
This deck was born of my "credit disparity" style deck where I would use ash/red herrings to put the runner into a spot where they either steal the agenda, and lost all their money, or they can't steal it and the astro train starts. This opened up a midseasons for a lot of tags, leading to fast advance from hand.

I've removed the whole midseasons combo and switched out TGTBT for BN to speed up the rush by adding score from hand.

This deck is more flexible in what it does, as it combines taxing with breaker snapping, and it packs enough ETR to be solid. Varied ice strength to help stop atman, and fun tricks like RSVP over Ash/melange/SanSan.

This is the deck I'll be taking to store championships if I continue to have bad luck with Running Bear's Midseason's combo deck with celebrity gift.

name: Noise HQ attack
description:
Building a noise deck for a friend, I'm publishing 2 versions, I'm curious which one looks better.

This one is more focused on virus mill, and passive econ, operating at a lower credit count, but still being as effective as possible. Lots of virus recursion to smash into HQ as hard as possible. Wyrm is expensive, but works very well with parasite.

We're trying to avoid crypsis + wyrm since crypsis's overhead costs is high, but cyberfeeder can offset that some.

Compare this to the one I'm posting next

name: Noise HQ attack2
description:
Building a noise deck for a friend, I'm publishing 2 versions, I'm curious which one looks better.

This one has overall fewer mills, but uses more denial and more draw, while having more active economy (which means more of it). This one lacks clone chip which means more work will be done by wyrm on breaking, which is expensive, but again this build has more economy

We're trying to avoid crypsis + wyrm since crypsis's overhead costs is high, but cyberfeeder can offset that some.

Compare this to the one I posted before.

name: kate parasite
Clever deck name
description:
This deck was born of my "credit disparity" style deck where I would use ash/red herrings to put the runner into a spot where they either steal the agenda, and lost all their money, or they can't steal it and the astro train starts. This opened up a midseasons for a lot of tags, leading to fast advance from hand.

I've removed the whole midseasons combo and switched out TGTBT for BN to speed up the rush by adding score from hand.

This deck is more flexible in what it does, as it combines taxing with breaker snapping, and it packs enough ETR to be solid. Varied ice strength to help stop atman, and fun tricks like RSVP over Ash/melange/SanSan.

This is the deck I'll be taking to store championships if I continue to have bad luck with Running Bear's Midseason's combo deck with celebrity gift.

name: HS-BRD 3.0
description: 3rd version of my HB Fast Advance, now with interns.

name: All the Bad Cards v1.0
description:
Experimental deck designed to.try and.find utility in "bad" cards like Motivation, Eureka!, Hard at Work, etc.

Bleed feed credits such as Daily Casts, Underworld Contacts and Hard at Work means less click intensive credit gain. Aesop's Pawnshop can clear an early H@W when you have the money for click intensive installation, but it's ideally for late game (ph3) where you're fully set up, need to make fewer runs, and can afford to let that click go. Potentially getting five click-free credits a turn with two more from the Toolbox is a decent income but burst credits off Kati Jones might improve the running ability if you can time it right.

Originally designed as a Monolith deck, the breakers were chosen to be all 4-cost, maximising the discount for installation, saving 12 credits, three clicks, and so only costing an effective three credits for the Console. Motivation / Eureka! can reduce the up-front cost, too. In practice the install cost was beyond the deck economy, stalling running until the full rig was in play cost games (esp. vs. Fast Advance) and so the cost / benefit wasn't being realised. Switching to The Toolbox overcame my psych block of waiting for the combination to come together.

It's still too slow. Tollbooth gives it kittens, sucking up seven credits to the GB, which is a turns worth of free credits. More draw, search and some kind of win accelerator is needed, so throwing the floor open to suggestions here ;-)

name: Newsbomb
Plan A: FA (v1.0)
description:
First pass at Jinteki fast advance. The idea is to rush match point by scoring agendas behind early Hives and/or Mushin No Shin + Himitsu-Bako. By the time Hive is down to one subroutine, the economy operations should make rezzing Tollbooths feasible to open a scoring window for the last agenda while the Runner is getting out a Femme. Either way, though, the Runner will more or less be obligated to run on your advanced remotes, which makes match point the perfect time for Junebug / Plan B / Toshiyuki Sakai shenanigans -- particularly with Mushin No Shin.

Zaibatsu Loyalty is in there because I think expose effects are going to be much more prevalent by the time Honor and Profit is released.

I did consider a Matrix Analyzer / Closed Accounts version as well, to try and keep the Runner poor for that last scoring window. That's still an option, but having no ice over strength 3 made me nervous.

name: Kit Pass
The world is amazing
How to Start a War and Still Score Agendas in the Morning
description:
This is my favourite corp deck ever, although I'd hardly call it competitive. The premise is simple; try to out economy the runner through your operations economy while protecting your centrals with a mix of ETR and destroyer ice. Scoring a Profiteering and taking the full 15 should set you for life.

Once you're ahead by a significant margin, let the runner grab an agenda and get replacin'. Psychographics now works on all your 2 point agendas for huge effect. Score PSF to lock the runner. Score Vitruvius with a few tokens to recur your economy and Psychographics. Score Mandatory Upgrades and enjoy your worry-free 4th click (and if you have PSF, its effectively over.) And finally, the key to (and the impetus for) the deck: Project Ares. Do you have any idea how satisfying it is to crush the runner's entire rig in a single turn? If they lack redundancies for their breakers your ETR ice will keep them out for the rest of the game, and the BP you accumulated can't hurt you.

Lots of fun to play and full of surprises. It's just a pity it falls down to any kind of economy denial and strong breaker recursion...

name: Mathematically Significant v1.2
description: An early set deck designed to give you assets and upgrades that can make the cost of a run confusing. Built with limited cards so there aren't many possibilities but seems to hold its own against the average runner deck.

name: Mac & Cheese 3.0
description: Kate is travelling light with her portable rig of recurring tricks.

name: Sundew Server Flood
